intro: Commiphora crassispina, commonly known as the rough-stemmed myrrh, is a shrub or small tree native to parts of Africa and the Arabian Peninsula. It belongs to the Burseraceae family, which includes other resin-producing plants like frankincense and myrrh. The plant is characterized by its rough, spiny stems and small, leathery leaves. It produces a fragrant resin that has been used historically in traditional medicine and incense. The botanical features of Commiphora crassispina make it an important species in both ecological and cultural contexts.
